title: Prompt-to-Leaderboard: A Natural Language Approach to Model Evaluation
author: Evan Frick (University of California, Berkeley), Connor Chen (University of California, Berkeley), Joseph Tennyson (University of California, Berkeley), Tianle Li (University of California, Berkeley), Wei-Lin Chiang (University of California, Berkeley), Anastasios N. Angelopoulos (University of California, Berkeley), Ion Stoica (University of California, Berkeley)
relevance_why: The P2L method's ability to produce prompt-specific performance evaluations may enhance audio processing models by allowing for tailored assessments of audio generation tasks based on user queries, improving model selection and interaction strategies.
background: Evaluating the performance of large language models (LLMs) effectively and specifically on a prompt-by-prompt basis to capture heterogeneous performance variations.
contribution: Prompt-to-Leaderboard introduces a novel methodology for evaluating language models by generating prompt-specific leaderboards, enhancing evaluation granularity and model routing.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Existing evaluation methods aggregate model performance metrics, leading to a loss of nuances in specific contexts.
technical_comparison.novelty: P2L integrates a conditional approach using natural language prompts to yield tailored performance scores, overcoming the limitations of aggregated metrics.

key_innovation: The use of Bradley-Terry coefficients derived from user preferences to create highly contextualized performance assessments for LLMs.
real_world_impact: P2L offers a practical tool for model selection and evaluation in various applications, leading to improved user interactions and outcomes in systems relying on LLMs, potentially benefiting areas like customer support and content generation.
limitations: No limitations were explicitly mentioned by the authors.

new_terms.Bradley-Terry model: **Bradley-Terry model** is a statistical method used to predict outcomes of pairwise comparisons, often employed in ranking scenarios to calculate the probabilities of outcomes based on relative strength.

open_sourcing: Code is available at GitHub: https://github.com/lmarena/p2l
